Why imposition of US healthcare rather than Germany, Swedish or French? Most of Europe operates private insurance topping up state insurance, several have minor charges for GP visits etc and many have strict qualification criteria and ID cards to ensure treatment is only paid for citizens. All of which have been suggested for the NHS and rejected by public opinion.

Most of European healthcare systems include things that would be unacceptable to people in the UK if introduced to the NHS.
For example France has an ID card system to prove who you are and that you are eligible for treatment, Sweden charges a small amount for GP visits, Germany refunds the bulk of treatment costs and then the rest is refunded by private insurance etc etc all of these things were suggested for the NHS and each time cries of "evil Tories" "facsists" are screamed until nothing can be done. This happened during the Blair years in the UK. White working class areas that had always voted Labour began to have more and more immigrants arrive and settle in the areas. The government lied again and again about the numbers of immigrants coming in. The locals could see the govt was lying but if they said anything they were called bigots/racist which immediately shut down their right to have an opinion and the debate. The problem was it was the truth on the ground and when the Govt gave the locals the brush off they turned to anti immigrant groups. Immigrants numbers did cause problems and did make local services worse because the national government was not funding the councils for the newly arrived populations. It wasn't until local labour councils began saying openly there were too many migrants for their services that the problem was addressed. Margret Hodge (local Labour MP) went door to door and fought the far right candidates in elections and when the working class locals were spoken to as humans and their concerns taken seriously the support for the far right evaporated.
In Scotland there is far far less immigration and pressure on local services is for different reasons but still the local working class areas were taken for granted by the Labour machine in power for decades, there was real shock when overnight the SNP gutted Labour Scotland.
People don't like being taken for granted and even if they work in a warehouse or shop they can tell when they are being patronised or spoken to condescendingly. Left wing or right wing, much of the voting is anti-establishment and should be a wake up call to the political class to reengage and listen to all voters not just each other and people like themselves.

All Scotch whisky has to be aged 3 years to be called scotch. That is 3 years as judged by the tax office (legal requirement) if they manage the dates right it can do just over 2 years in a bonded warehouse and it now qualifies as "Scotch". The named single malt distilleries used to send upwards of 70% of their produce to the big name conglomerate blends like famous grouse, teachers etc where it would be mixed with other 3 year olds and grain whisky to make the standard blends which are the bulk of the scotch whisky market. This gave them the revenue stream to support the development of their "real" product the 10 plus aged whiskies that are their own brand.
But now virtually all the Scotch whisky malt makers are owned by huge transnational companies that finance the creation of brands, huge marketing budgets, product placement into the Asian markets and the aging of stock. There is also the marketing creation of "special" non aged stock branding so the distillery with a big name single malt will call it something like dark storm sherry cask and charge premium price for it but omit the fact it has not been aged at all so the mark up is crazy.

The bike would make a great tourer. Think of all the bikepacking and pannier touring now done on MTBs, fast touring done on cross bikes/road bikes, your hybrid would be great but you probably do want a triple if you are climbing hills fully loaded. You are right about it being a cost/time/effort judgement. If you still have to buy panniers/rack etc then it will probably cost you a minimum of 300 to convert. It might be easier to buy a new bike already with triple gears and sell the one you have. One thing to be wary of is buying secondhand unless you get a really good look at it or know/trust the seller. So many secondhand "bargins" need wheels trued/serviced/new bottom bracket/new cassette/chain etc and that can quite quickly eat away any savings over a new bike.
Convert yours or not? Up to you and DIY would mean you could fix it all yourself on your next round the world trip. It would work out cheaper but probably only by a few hundred. It would take time and lots of youtube videos or visits to local bike co op to get help plus tools. If you do decide to do it here are some links about parts to give you an idea of costs/options etc
Handle bars - Drop bars are good but so are butterfly bars and flatbars with good bar ends that give multiple hand positions. Flatbar gears shifters/brakes go straight onto butterfly bars.
https://www.sjscycles.co.uk/handlebars/sjsc-ergo-control-bar-end-grip-black/ https://www.sjscycles.co.uk/handlebars-other/ https://www.cyclestore.co.uk/alloy_comfort_trekking_bar_590mm_sil_ral-ID_9331
Saddle - I tour in road bike shorts on a mtb saddle very comfy and cheaper than brooks.
https://www.cyclestore.co.uk/madison_flux_mtb_mens_saddle-ID_65254?gclid=CMn3qNLbzc4CFSEW0wodeGkP2A gclsrc=aw.ds
Gears/Transmission/Make it a triple :
You can buy a complete Shimano Deore triple groupset for about 160ish, if you can fit it yourself that would be cheaper than buying triple conversion pieces for your sora flatbar groupset (chainset 75?, front derailleur 20?, shifter 80). The bike shop is a good price inc labour and non sora parts will be just as good for touring.
https://www.merlincycles.com/shimano-deore-m610-triple-transmission-groupset-70201.html http://www.ribblecycles.co.uk/shimano-sora-3503-9spd-triple-front-gear/ http://www.ribblecycles.co.uk/shimano-sora-triple-3503-9spd-chainset/ https://www.cyclestore.co.uk/shimano_fc3503_sora_2_piece_design_triple_chainset_9speed-ID_59138 https://www.cyclestore.co.uk/productDetails.asp?productID=59142
If you are able to go lightweight then you would be fine with a double chainset so just put bar ends on, rack and panniers and off you go!
Here is a link to a good blog about touring with tons of info about different styles of touring and touring bikes. http://tomsbiketrip.com/cheap-touring-bikes-for-low-budget-bicycle-adventures-a-growing-list/

Artillery in battle is used on an area of ground rather than a specific individual target. So you might fire it at tanks to make them close down their hatches, try to damage their optics and radios making it easier for anti tank weapons engage them. Or use it on a piece of ground to direct the enemy into a killing zone. Or to suppress an enemy position while you move troops to assault it (or withdraw). It does all these things in all weathers whilst out of sight of the enemy and very cheaply compared to multiple layers of ground attack aircraft. Also good at providing smoke and illumination. Plus it is probably part of the ground troops own formation so is more likely to be there all the time when air power might not be. In a modern war it is still useful, even in counter insurgency where you probably wouldn't use multiple gunlines pre smashing the target area because of civilian casualties. You could put it in a remote location (very little maintenance or support required) and be able to hit enemy mortar, rocket firing positions that would be out of range of infantry weapons (even anti-tank weapons like Javelin).
TL:DR Very useful. Artillery is cheap, all weather, out of sight, easy to maintain, a very good area weapon and very good at supporting ground troops.
